article.paragraph: Forother people with similar namesAlexander of Serbia (disambiguation)Alexander of Yugoslavia (disambiguation)Infobox royaltyAlexander I [[List of Serbian monarchs|King of Serbia]] AlejandroIDeSerbiaEn1900.jpg 2 July 1889 6 March 1889 – 11 June 1903 [[Milan I of Serbia|Milan I]] [[Peter I of Serbia|Peter I]] [[Draga Mašin]] [[House of Obrenović]] [[Milan I of Serbia|Milan I]] [[Natalie of Serbia|Natalija Keşco]] {{birth date|1876|08|14|df[[Belgrade]], [[Principality of Serbia|Serbia]] {{death date and age|1903|06|11|1876|08|14|dfBelgrade, [[Kingdom of Serbia|Serbia]] [[St. Mark's Church, Belgrade|St. Mark's Church]], Belgrade Infobox royal styles[[File:Royal Monogram of King Alexander I of Serbia.svg|50px]] Alexander I of Serbia [[Majesty|His Majesty]] Your Majesty Sir Alexander IorAleksandar Obrenovi(Serbian Cyrillic alphabetCyrillic: ; 14 August 1876 11 June 1903) was king ofSerbiafrom 1889 to 1903 when he and his wife, Queen Draga, wereMay Coup (Serbia)assassinatedby a group of Army officers,cite bookDorichWilliamKosovo0-317-05074-5led by CaptainDragutin Dimitrijevi.
article.heading: Accession
article.paragraph: File:Divlad Miln szerb kirly 1888-32.jpgthumbleft150pxYoung Alexander with his father KingMilan I of SerbiaMilanin 1888 less than a year before Milan abdicated the throne in favour of his underage son.In 1889 Alexander's father,Milan I of SerbiaKing Milan, unexpectedly abdicated and withdrew to private life, proclaiming Alexander king of Serbia under a regency until he should attain his majority at eighteen years of age. His motherNatalie of SerbiaNatalija Obrenovibecame his regent. His parents were second cousins.

In 1893, King Alexander, aged sixteen, arbitrarily proclaimed himself of full age, dismissed theregentsand their government, and took the royal authority into his own hands. His action won popular support, as did his appointment of a radical ministry.sfnChisholm1911

In May 1894 King Alexander arbitrarily abolished King Milan's liberal constitution of 1888 and restored the conservative one of 1869. His attitude during theGreco-Turkish War (1897)was one of strictNeutrality (international relations)neutrality.sfnChisholm1911

In 1894 the young King brought his father, Milan, back to Serbia and, in 1898, appointed him commander-in-chief of the Serbian army. During that time, Milan was regarded as thede factoruler of the country.sfnChisholm1911
article.heading: Marriage
article.paragraph: File:Aleksandar ob heinrich wassmuth 1894.jpgthumbright150pxKing Alexander 1894.In the summer of 1900, King Alexander suddenly announced his engagement to the widowed MadameDraga Main, formerly a lady-in-waiting to his mother and 12 years older than him. The projected union initially aroused great opposition: he did not consult with his father, who had been on vacation inKarlovy Varyand making arrangements to secure the hand ofGermanyGermanprincessPrince William of Schaumburg-Lippe#MarriageAlexandra zu Schaumburg-Lippefor his son, or hisPrime Minister of SerbiaPrime MinisterDr. Vladan orevi, who was visiting theParisWorld ExhibitionUniversal Exhibitionat the time of the announcement. Both immediately resigned from their respective offices and Alexander had difficulty in forming a new cabinet. Alexander's mother also opposed the marriage and was subsequently banished from the kingdom. She was known to have been seen in the nearby countries, such as Austria-Hungary and Bulgaria.

Opposition to the union seemed to subside somewhat for a time upon the publication ofTsar Nicholas II's congratulations to the king on his engagement and of his acceptance to act as the principal witness at the wedding. The marriage duly took place in August 1900. Even so, the unpopularity of the union weakened the King's position in the eyes of the army and of the country at large.sfnChisholm1911
article.heading: Politics and the constitution
article.paragraph: File:Aleksandar Obrenovic.jpgthumbright150pxKing Alexander and Queen DragaFile:Obrenoviceva vila u Smederevu.jpgthumbright150pxSummer residence of King Alexander inSmederevo.King Alexander tried to reconcile political parties by unveiling aclassical liberalismliberalconstitutionof his own initiative, introducing for the first time in the constitutional history of Serbia the system of two chambers (National Assembly of Serbiaskuptinaandsenate). This reconciled the political parties but did not reconcile the army which, already dissatisfied with the king's marriage, became still more so at the rumors that one of the two unpopular brothers ofDraga MainQueen Draga, Lieutenant Nikodije, was to be proclaimed heir-presumptive to the throne.sfnChisholm1911

Meanwhile, the independence of thesenateand of the council of state caused increasing irritation to King Alexander. In March 1903 the King suspended theconstitutionfor half an hour, time enough to publish the decrees dismissing and replacing the old senators and councillors of state. This arbitrary act naturally increased dissatisfaction in the country.
article.heading: Assassination
article.paragraph: mainMay OverthrowThe general impression was that, as much as thesenatewas packed with men devoted to the royal couple and the government obtained a large majority at the general elections, King Alexander would not hesitate any longer to proclaim Queen Draga's brother as theheir presumptiveto the throne. In spite of this, it had been agreed with the Serbian Government thatPrince Mirko of Montenegro, who was married toNatalija Konstantinovic, the granddaughter ofPrincess Anka Obrenovi, an aunt of King Milan, would be proclaimed heir-presumptive in the event that the marriage of King Alexander and Queen Draga was childless.Cite webLeroyPierre Olivierhttp://www.njegoskij.org/menu_history/subArts_2006/subArtHI_05006.php#footnotesBiography of Prince Mihajlo Petrovic NjegosSeptember 28, 2007The Njegoskij Fund Public Project2004http://web.archive.org/web/20070927034426/http://www.njegoskij.org/menu_history/subArts_2006/subArtHI_05006.php27 September 2007noDead linkSeptember 2010H3llBot

Apparently to prevent Queen Draga's brother being named heir-presumptive, but in reality to replace Alexander Obrenovi withPeter I of SerbiaPeter Karaorevi, a conspiracy was organized by a group of Army officers headed by CaptainDragutin Dimitrijevialso known as "Apis", and Norman Perovi, a young Greek Orthodox militant who was in the pay of theRussian EmpireRussians,C. L. Sulzberger,The Fall of Eagles, p.202, Crown Publishers, New York, 1977as well as the leader of theBlack Hand (Serbia)Black Handsecret societywhich would assassinateArchduke Franz Ferdinand of AustriaArchduke Franz Ferdinandin 1914. Several politicians were also part of the conspiracy, and allegedly included former Prime Minister,Nikola Pai.Sulzberger, p.202The royal couple'sThe Old Palacepalacewas invaded and they hid in a cupboard in the Queen's bedroom. (There is another possibility, used in a Serbian TV history series "The End of the Obrenovi Dynasty" in which the royal couple was hidden in a secretpanic roomhidden behind the mirror in a common bedroom. The room contained an entrance to a secret passage leading out of the palace, but the entrance was inaccessible due to the placement of the queen's wardrobe over it after the wedding.)

The conspirators searched the palace and eventually discovered the royal couple and murdered them in the early morning of May 29, 1903. King Alexander and Queen Draga were shot and their bodies mutilated and disemboweled and, according to eyewitness accounts, thrown from a second floor window of the palace onto piles of garden manure.The King was only 26 years old at the time of his death. King Alexander and Queen Draga were buried in the crypt ofSt. Mark's Church, Belgrade.
